SPEC.RARE.73
Samuel Sullivan Cox's "Journal of a Tour to Europe" is a leather-bound notebook approximately 6.5 in. (16.5 cm.) tall by 4 in. (10 cm.) wide. Its pages are unlined and unnumbered. A label in the upper left-hand corner of the paste-down endpaper inside the front cover indicates that the notebook was "Sold by / Wm. W. Rose / Stationer. / 19 Wall St. N.Y." The following text is scratched into the outside of the original front cover: "S. Cox / Zanesville / Ohio / (U.S.A.)"
When acquired by the Ohio State University Libraries in 2005, Cox's journal was in very delicate condition. Its leather binding was cracked and peeled, the spine was missing, the stitching was so loose that the text block was in danger of falling apart, and several leaves had become separated from their conjugates or completely loose. Before the pages of the journal were scanned for this edition, the journal was disbound and the gatherings repaired by Harry Campbell, Book and Paper Conservator with the Conservation Division of The Ohio State University Libraries. Once scanning was complete, the volume was resewn and rebound. The original boards, binding, and sewing supports were retained and are boxed with the restored journal.
The state of the original volume makes complete description conjectural, but the following comparison between the orginal and restored volumes will help users relate the page images contained in this edition to the two states of the journal.
Original. The front endpapers may have consisted of four leaves as follows: the paste-down endpaper, two conjugate leaves, and (conjecturally) a missing flyleaf or stub, all forming a separate section at the front. The text block proper was a straightforward 16º: [A-H]10; 80 leaves. The back endpapers may have consisted of the paste-down endpaper and (conjecturally) a missing flyleaf or stub.
Restored. The front endpapers consist of the original paste-down endpaper with the inside hinge area reinforced with sympathetic repair tissue. The text block is 16º: [A]12 (+A1.2) [B-H]10; 82 leaves. The back endpapers consist of the original paste-down endpaper with the inside hinge area reinforced by sympathetic repair tissue.
The journal is written mostly in brown ink on off-white paper that has taken on a bluish tint over time. When at sea, Cox often wrote first in pencil, then at some later time traced over his text in ink, perhaps to avoid spilling or smearing ink when the seas were rough. In most places where this overwriting occurs, it closely follows and all but obscures the penciled text. Where the texts diverge, the differences typically consist of changes to line breaks or punctuation that do not alter meaning. Nevertheless, in order to reflect this unique palimpsest-like character of the text, we encode passages consisting of both pencil and ink versions in which differences are legible. For those cases, a button in the right margin allows readers to toggle between the two versions.
Selection of Source Material. This journal is the only manuscript by Samuel Sullivan Cox in The Ohio State University Libraries' collection, and it is edited here in its entirety. It provides an interesting look at a working draft of material that would find its way into publication as part of A Buckeye Abroad (1852).

note.p: Samuel Sullivan Cox (1824–1889) served as a Democratic congressman in the United States House of Representative from 1856 until his death, save for a few short interruptions, first representing his native Ohio (he was born in Zanesville) and then, from 1868 onward, his adopted state of New York. As a public servant, he is most remembered, even revered, for strengthening the Life-Saving Service (a precursor to the Coast Guard) and improving the working conditions of mail carriers. As a Democratic politician, his legacy is marred by his oft-assumed role as spokesperson for his party's resistance to abolition and emancipation during the years leading up to the Civil War. As an author, Cox published articles and books throughout his life on political and popular subjects, including six travel books. But in May 1851, Cox was a twenty-six-year-old Brown University graduate who had moved back to Ohio to practice law and had recently married (Peskin). On May 7, he and his wife Julia (née Buckingham, whom he married in October 1849), along with her brother Philo Buckingham and a cousin, Lucy Sturges, set sail on a long-delayed honeymoon tour of Europe and the Orient (Linsey 204–205).

The manuscript journal presented in this edition records Cox's experiences and reflections during the trip, but it also serves as a sketch pad for an expanded account of the voyage that Cox published the following year, A Buckeye abroad; or, Wanderings in Europe and in the Orient (1852). Appearing seventeen years before Mark Twain's more famous debut as a travel writer, The Innocents Abroad; or, The New Pilgrims Progress (1869), A Buckeye Abroad is still far from the first account in English of a "grand tour" of Europe. Both Twain and Cox offer similar apologia for publishing yet another account of a grand tour. Twain presents himself as everyman, rather than guide or critic:
note.q: Yet notwithstanding it is only a record of a picnic, it has a purpose, which is to suggest to the reader how he would be likely to see Europe and the East if he looked at them with his own eyes instead of the eyes of those who traveled in those countries before him. (xvii)
note.p: Cox presents a similarly self-effacing ethos:
note.q: The only merit reserved for a volume of travels is, either that the ground is untrodden, or that the mode of observation is new and peculiar. The author can lay no claim to the former. Something may be conceded to him, from the fact imported by the title—A Buckeye Abroad. A native of the west, and of that part, familiarly known as the Buckeye State,—may be supposed to look upon the scenes and mingle with the throngs of the Old World with new and peculiar sensations, which may find sympathy, if not with the general reader, at least with readers in Ohio. (5)
note.p: Of course, the degree to which Cox (or Twain, for that matter) presents "new and peculiar" views of Europe to his contemporaries is open to interpretation. In Cox's notes about each stage of his party's journey, however, twenty-first-century readers are sure to find insights into an historical and cultural milieu removed in time and sensibility from our own—even as we recognize long-enduring conventions of travel and tourism as well as familiar dynamics of cross-cultural encounters.
Crossing the Atlantic

Describing his party's departure from Jersey City, NJ in the RMS Asia on May 7, Cox conveys excitement, confidence, and eager anticipation. Still within sight of land, he enthuses, they spotted a young whale: "Hurrah! He spouted away throwing the spray 20 ft. high. No sensation of sickness yet. All is exhileration." Not for long. On May 8th, he writes with determination, "Sick to day, but able to be about. . . . I had to keep on deck today—or give in." The next day his mood turns: "Lay wretchedly all morning," he tells us, "Realized the horrors." Then he falls silent until May 13, unable in the interim "to do anything except lay sick." Cox's bout with sea-sickness was not the result of a particularly weak stomach; rather, it reminds us of the rigors of the early days of transatlantic passenger service on small steamships. The Asia, the largest ship in the British and North American Royal Mail Steam Packet Company's fleet when it was built the year before Cox's trip, was a wooden-hulled sidewheeler, 266 feet long by 40 wide with a gross tonnage of 2,226. By contrast, the current flagship of the Cunard Line, the Queen Mary 2, is 1,132 feet long by 135 feet wide abeam with an approximate gross tonnage of 151,400 (Cunard Line). The ride, in short, was rough in any seas. These early pages of Cox's journal also contain more subtle evidence of how violently the ship would pitch and roll. While most of the journal is written in ink, the pages composed at sea are written first in pencil, then traced over at some later date in ink. Presumably, Cox didn't trust himself on the bounding main with an open bottle of ink and a fountain pen!

In light of the discomfort he describes in ever more vivid prose (at one point he laments that his sensibilities have been reduced to the "nauseate sublime"), there is more than a little dramatic irony in his fascination with the technology of sailing. "Was there ever such perfection of enginery," he gushes at one point, "so massive yet so perfect; so powerful so fit." Yet he captures the public's fascination with the rapidly advancing technology of steamship travel, particularly the competition between the British Cunard Line and the American Collins Line during the 1850s to build ever bigger, more powerful ships that would provide the fastest, most elegant transatlantic crossing (Babcock 91–101). Cox provides a front-row view of that international competition in his description of the Asia's encounter with the U.S. steamer Humboldt (not a Collins ship) and his speculation that the Asia will beat the best crossing time of the Collins steamer Pacific.

Cox's prose, as much as his subjects, characterize him as a writer developing his distinctive voice. His writing—and sensibilities—are clearly informed by his reading. In the space of a single journal entry on May 13th, he quotes Washington Irving, Robert Burton, William Wordsworth, Jonathan Sewall, and Samuel Taylor Coleridge. He also draws on a rich—if sometimes overwrought—pictorial imagination, an ability to sketch sentimental and often didactic tableaux in words. Describing a small bird he sees somewhere off the coast of Nova Scotia or Newfoundland, Cox writes,
note.q: How beautiful would be the song of that little chorister upon a "bough swaying in the breeze" in some sequestered nook amid a leafy valley surrounded with green prospects & smiling cultivation. How like a hymn to its Creator would go up its carol to the All Audient creator;—yet here it is, with fagged wing & panting breast, contending with harsh cold blasts, just able to overtop the snow spray of the mid Ocean,—deluded from its home in the bosom of the wood by the mysteries of the Unknown, a thing of song in a sea of chaos—soon to [be] whelmed forever! Is it not an epitome of Man when he breaks the golden chords of that harmony which binds him to his God!
note.p: Cox's skill at this sort of writing would earn him the sobriquet "Sunset Cox" after the appearance in 1853 of an effusive description of a sunset published in The Ohio Statesman, a political journal that he owned and edited in Columbus, Ohio. Introducing a reprint of Cox's sunset essay in a 1910 volume of Ohio History, E. O. Randall calls Cox a "master word painter" (331). However, in his Preface to A Buckeye Abroad, Cox somewhat more modestly characterizes his literary allusions and descriptive prose as spontaneous plein air daguerreotypes of the scenes before him:
note.q: The impressions herein recorded were mostly taken upon the spot, and the allusions, historical, classical, or otherwise, were not sought for, but sprung out of the time and locality. Each lineament of each form in Nature or Art, each custom and characteristic were daguerreotyped, though somewhat rapidly, if not imperfectly, from the original, as it appeared in itself and in its environment. (6)
note.p: While it lies beyond the scope of this introduction to test Cox's claims, it is worth noting here that the journal, from the early entries onward, provides a rough means of gauging the spontaneity and directness of the writing in A Buckeye Abroad and the degree to which it results from revision and expansion.

As the Asia approaches Great Britain, Cox regains his sea legs and his appetite, finding the energy to explore the ship and even to appreciate, once again, the grandeur of the open ocean. Nevertheless, upon sight of the English coast, he enthuses, "And this is England! Glorious old England."
Liverpool

Cox's entries from Liverpool convey contagious amazement: "How can I describe my feelings at the grand illumination?" Inevitably, his impressions are filtered through his reading and cultural biases: He first introduces us to the social scene of Liverpool by describing a street urchin as a "veritable O. Twist, who in his tatters and with a bow & a touch of an apochryphal cap requested to carry the carpet bag."

With a storyteller's ear for dialogue, he transcribes the speech of colorful characters: "Soon came upon another liar. 'Waterloo Sir?' Sorry it's full Sir, I am boots there' Sir three ships just in hrs—Victoria Hotel is near—great hotel." With a travel writer's eye for landscape, architecture, and monuments, he provides a walking tour of Liverpool and its environs: "The Corinthian elegance of the architecture here & the neatness & well pavedness of the streets are permanent." And with a sketchbook artist's attention to detail, he occasionally draws a sketch in the margins of the journal.
London

Arriving in London on 19 May, Cox spends his first full day, Tuesday, May 20th, visiting the famous Crystal Palace, which housed the Great Exhibition of 1851, to view its "splendid contents." Over the next three days, he and his companions take in the Crystal Palace, an opera, the Epsom Derby, and a host of other tourist sites. They even indulge in a bit of paparazzi-style rubbernecking at royalty, seizing a chance to chase down Queen Victoria while riding in a hansom cab: "I asked the driver if it was the Queen, he said Yes—'Drive after them!' Away went the sovereign of Gt B. Away after went us Sovereigns in chase. . . . we got pretty close. Whereupon to our open Eyes and outstretched necks, the Queen herself turned round & gave us a good look & full view."

In addition to taking in the cultural sights—galleries, exhibitions, monuments, horse races, and royalty—this newly minted lawyer and future career politician makes a point of visiting the British Parliament. On May 23, he describes the (to his sensibilities chaotic) scene at the House of Commons and pastes into his journal a clipping from the Times recounting a debate on the Ecclesiastical Titles Assumptions bill.

Cox occasionally leavens his veneration of all things British with a pinch of Yankee pride, as he does when he declares the Princess Theatre at best only on par with the grandest theaters in the United States.

The journal also reveals the quotidian trials and details of extended international travel in 1851 (most of which still ring true today): Cox more than once loses track of the day and date, he repeatedly visits banks to deal with business back home or manage his funds (he stops by Barings bank in London), and he must regularly secure visas for upcoming legs of the journey.
Paris and Southern France

Cox arrives in Paris interested mainly in obtaining passports before moving on to Italy (or, more exactly, the various states that would comprise a united Italy after the 1860s and 70s), spending only one full day in the French capital, though a day he describes as "A perfect day of wonders." One special wonder turns out to be his own ability to speak French with his cabman: "My proficiency astonished me. Guess we can get along thro' France."

As the party heads south toward Italy and Rome, Cox takes particular note of the "Roman monuments in Gaul." Upon seeing a ruined viaduct in Avignon (probably the Pont du Gard) near which a proud new suspension bridge has been built, he exclaims, "How the old and new civilization is contrasted."
Sardinia and Tuscany

Traveling from Marseilles to Genoa (Sardinia), Cox encounters—and describes—other travelers from the U.S., as he does occasionally during his travels. On board the Languedoc, he meets the author Ann Sophia Stephens, who is traveling with George and Julia Pratt, the children of Judge Zadoch Pratt of New York. Cox describes Mrs. Stephens somewhat cryptically as "caustically agreeable."

Arriving in Leghorn (Tuscany) on June 4, Cox finds another reminder of home—the U.S.S. Mississippi—anchored in the port. On board the party meets the American sculptor Hiram Powers, most famous for his statue of the "Greek Slave" (1843), which was on display at the Great Exhibition. Significantly, given the political turmoil in Europe at this time, Cox's party will encounter several other U.S. warships during their travels, and Cox occasionally records discussions of politics with the locals.
"Eternal Rome" and the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies

Upon his arrival at the port of Civita Veccia, Cox offers his "verdict re. Italians," contrasting the "higher classes," whom he finds "decent, polite & refined," with the "lower classes," who "look hard, in dirty tatters, and with saucy deportment — mishaven and sallow—& seemingly incapable of a noble thought." He laments that they represent "the degenerate scion of the old Roman tree!" This tendency to interpret the appearance and living conditions of the poor in terms of character is all too familiar, but it is especially troubling and ironic given Cox's attention to political oppression elsewhere (later in his travels, he rails against Ferdinand II, "the brutal despot of Naples").
Rome, however, elicits Cox's veneration of Roman antiquities, which he describes with great detail in lengthy journal entries.
The "Dreamy Orient."

By contrast, Cox writes relatively little about Athens and Greece (and spends relatively little time there). En route to Constantinople via Smyrna, he describes islands nestled between the coasts of Greece and Turkey in the Aegean Sea: Tenedos, Lemnos, and Lesbos. After weaving through the Aegean, threading the Dardanelles, and steaming up the Bosphorus, the party finally arrives in the "Dreamy Orient."

Accompanied by an American consul and local firman, Cox and his company explore mosques (including the Hagia Sophia), seraglios, harems, splendid flower and fruit gardens, fountains of goldfish, and the "richly ornamented" tomb of Sultan Mahmoud II.

Stopping at Smyrna on their return, Cox and Philo take a traditional Turkish bath, and Cox records a sensuously detailed account of the process: "The attendant rubs us with glove hand with warm water, which is grateful & good. He pours bowl on bowl over the entranced body until the frame almost chills with delight. The head forms the point from which the dripping water falls all around. A soft & pleasant sensation comes over the mind; not intense & thrilling; but mellowed & tender as a sunset would produce or a picture of Murillo. Soon P & I began to throw the warm water at each other; in the mean time the sweat running, & the sensation robbing the body of all save enjoyment." Not surprisingly, Cox omits most of this private description from A Buckeye Abroad.
Trieste, Venetia, and Lombardy

Cox's party returns to Italy at Trieste (at the time, part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire), then heads west to Venice, Verona, and Brescia on the way to Milan and Lake Como, crossing Venetzia and Lombardy. In Trieste, we are reminded again of the tumultuous history of mid-century Europe: "Germans & Italians, Russian Soldiers & Austrian, peasants & merchants, all mingling in the shouts & Joy of a Sunday night." At Verona, Cox again encounters Europe's nobility: "The train of the Elector of Saxony & Queen started just before ours. He stopped at our Hotel, beat us at the Tower this morng, & is in many respects an energetic fellow." Throughout these pages, though, Cox focuses on the stuff of travel writing: the people's dress and occupations, the landscape, architectural details, associations from literature and art. The party arrives in Lake Como on July 18, 1851. Cox has filled his journal and, before beginning a new volume, he takes a moment to reflect on his travels: "How much of the round Earth has been seen! What has it bought us? Humility, Charity Kindness & Tenderness, No, these are plants, which grow in the shade of home, not the sun & air of the World. It is to be hoped that the gentler virtues & the primal duties will be better cultivated hereafter in our own homes." Unfortunately, we do not have the second journal, but we can follow the rest of the voyage in A Buckeye Abroad.

projectDesc.p: This edition belongs to a series of collaboratively produced electronic editions of previously unpublished nineteenth-century American manuscripts held in the Rare Books and Manuscripts Library (RBMS) at The Ohio State University Libraries. Other editions include "Selected Entries from the Lucius Clark Smith Diaries, 30 July 1862 to 31 December 1862"; "My Dear Elizabeth," five letters written by Sophia Peabody Hawthorne to her sister Elizabeth Palmer Peabody between ca. 1837 and 1868; and Louisa A. Doane's "Journal of Two Ocean Voyages (1852-1853)."

Each text was initially edited in connection with an undergraduate or graduate course on electronic textual editing offered by H. Lewis Ulman, Associate Professor of English at The Ohio State University. The courses provided students with an opportunity to explore issues of textuality and mediation that arise when our cultural archives spread from page to screen and from library shelves to networked databases. Electronic textual editing served as each class's context for examining what happens—and envisioning what might happen—when artifacts in one medium are represented in another medium, especially with regard to the interpretive work of reading. Electronic textual editions also provided a contact zone that helped students reflect on what manuscript, print, and "born digital" artifacts can tell us about their unique properties and their relationships to one another.

While the students' work focused on providing reliable textual editions, they also explored four threads inextricably woven into the work of electronic textual editing: the lives and historical milieu evoked by the texts; the history, characteristics, and preservation of physical and digital texts; the editorial processes and decisions that shape particular interpretations and presentations texts; and the mediation of electronic delivery systems.

These conceptual focuses, along with the time constraints of academic terms and the need to train students who had, typically, no prior experience in textual editing or the various technologies employed in electronic textual editing, strongly influenced the selection of texts in this series. Working with curators in the RBMS, Professor Ulman identified previously unpublished manuscript materials that were of potentially broad interest and that reflected a curatorial focus of the RBMS collection—for example, letters and personal diaries that connect private lives with larger historical contexts. Focusing on unique manuscript materials not, in all but one case, associated with other copies or later published versions also eliminated the need to compare multiple copies or states of the same work, perhaps held in other archives, an impractical task in the course of an academic term. Other practical matters also informed the choice of materials, including the possibility of scanning the source documents before the class so that students could work with both the original documents and high-resolutions facsimiles as they transcribed and encoded the source texts.

Thus, the editions in this series are documentary editions—interpretations and representations of single documents—designed to provide wider exposure and access to manuscript materials that might otherwise be overlooked, and to provide users with a variety of tools for studying those texts.

While providing a reliable textual edition is a sine qua non, the Stephens edition also explores ways of telling four stories inextricably woven into our work: the lives and historical milieu evoked by the texts, the history of the physical documents, the editorial process that gave rise to this particular interpretation of the texts, and the mediation of our electronic delivery system.

Over the course of several years following the classes in which students worked on the editions, Professor Ulman revised the introductory materials to ensure stylistic consistency and proofed the transcription and encoding. He also redesigned the structure of the editions to meet the requirements of Ohio State's institutional repository, evolving accessibility standards, and feedback from peer reviewers. However, he did not undertake a complete retranscription of the source text or revision of the students' introductory essays and annotations.

editorialDecl.p: Scanning. The manuscript pages were scanned as 24-bit TIFF images at 400 dots per inch (dpi), then coverted to 8-bit JPEG images at 400 dpi and full quality. All edges were overscanned by at least 1/4 inch. No color correction was used at any stage of image preparation, but a scan of a photographer's 18% grey card on the same scanner produced RGB values at the center of 91/95/107 after applying a 150% Gaussian Blur in Adobe Photoshop to average color values. Thus, a properly configured monitor should provide a reasonable approximation of colors on the manuscript pages..

Transcription. Editing of the Cox journal emphasizes diplomatic transcription: abbreviations, recoverable cancelations, punctuation, spelling, underlining, additions above and below the line or in the margins, capitalization, line breaks, and page breaks have all been transcribed and encoded as they appear in the original manuscripts. The representation of those features varies depending on the view of the letter. An explanation of the presentation in each view of the letters can be read via the "About this View" link at the top of each view's page.

Markup and Annotation. XML encoding of the Anderson letters follows The Text Encoding Initiative's (TEI) P5: Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange, as customized for the project using the TEI's ODD ("One Document Does it All") process. This editorial introduction and the three "views" of the letters were generated from the main XML file using XSL transformations to produce HTML Web pages. Several of the appendices were encoded in HTML separately. A more detailed description of the markup can be found via the "Appendices" menu, and all source files (XML, XSL, CSS, ODD, RNC) can be viewed and downloaded via the "Source Files" menu.

Introductory material (such as this editorial introduction) as well as annotated lists of people, places, ships, and organizations mentioned in the letters are encoded in the TEI header of the main XML document. Other explanatory annotations are linked directly from the text. Separate appendices provide further information about the project (e.g., acknowledgements, editors' bios, and so on). All these ancillary materials can be viewed via the menus at the top of each page.

Proofing. Students who created the original transcriptions proofread their own transcription and encoding. In preparation for peer review by NINES and preservation in The Ohio State University's Knowledge Bank, the transcriptions and encoding were once again proofread by Professor Ulman.
Peer Review. Anonymous reviewers for NINES provided peer-reviews for the editions, in response to which they were revised and then reviewed by NINES editors before being listed in the NINES database.

Production and Archival Location of Digital Assets. All of the files associated with this edition are accessed via, and archived in, The Ohio State University's institutional repository, the Knowledge Bank.

Various manuscript features (e.g., cancellations, interlinear or marginal additions, tears in pages) are encoded, as are regularized versions of proper names and dates and standard versions of nonstandard spellings and expansions of abbreviations. div.head:
Log of the Asia
The Asia was built in 1850 for the British and North American Royal Mail Steam Packet Company (renamed the Cunard Steam Ship Co. Ltd. in 1878) by R. Steele & Son of Greenock, Scotland. It was a wooden-hulled paddlewheeler, 266 feet long by 40 wide, with a gross tonnage of 2,226 and an indicated horse-power 2,150, making it, along with its sister ship Africa (built by Steele & Son the same year), the largest ship at the time in the Cunard fleet (Swiggum and Kohli; Hyde 326–327). The Asia departed on its maiden voyage, from Liverpool to New York, on May 18, 1850 (Solem and Austheim).

cell.note: Cox miscalculates the total miles, which add up to 2738, using the figures in his corrected transcription of the ship's log.

dateline.note: The text of Cox's journal contains sections written in pencil, sections written in ink, and sections in which text written originally in pencil is overwritten (and, in a very few cases, altered) in ink. Based on the headings and content of the journal entries, we assume that the original text of Cox's journal was written in pencil when he was onboard a ship at sea (perhaps to avoid spilling ink) and in ink when he was on land or on a ship lying at anchor. The penciled passages overwritten in ink were presumably composed at sea and overwritten later, perhaps to create a copy less prone to fading. Because the pencil and superimposed ink copies of passages vary so little, only differences between the pencil and ink text have been encoded, and we provide a button allowing readers to display each version.

div.p:
Left Jersey City dock in the 'Asia'
—
CaptCaptain
Judkins. Ret.Retired The day was fine, the
Sun shone—no white caps to the
waves. All our baggage being a-
board, we went amid the throng
on deck. The boat was crowded
with passengers and friends.
Coe et uxuxor (just married yesterday) Presumably Rev. Henry Issac Coe (b. 1826). A classmate of Cox's at Brown University, Coe married Laura Ann Fletcher on May 6, 1851 (Davis 115–116; Brown University 151; Bartlett 261–261).
came over—Henry Clark we saw,
& spoke to, on the dock. We began
to move away at 12 M.meridies—

We moved out most gallantly
All the passengers on the deck ,
& the
dock dark crowded our friends were there— The crowd cheered as we left—
Six times our guns fired as we
swept past the battery & Castle gar
den. Julia Samuel Sullivan Cox and Julia Ann Buckingham were married in October 1849 (Lindsey 8). & Lucy According to David Lindsey, Lucy was a cousin of Julia and her brother, Philo Buckinham (205). trembled at each
report. A few tears—! NYNew York began to
die away in the distance. The lines
of masts grew thinner. The Battery
seemed a clump of trees. We
passed the Narrows ,
when we hailed
a vessel mark W. to take off our
Pilot—

This was done very prettily—
The little boat dropped astern
and &
we moved away throbbingly—We
were not out of land-sight
before
there was seen a something spouting be-
fore there was seen a something
salt water against the sky.
spouting salt water against the
An old naval officer—a regular
sky. An old naval officer—a
JohnyJohnny Bull who sat near us
regular JohnyJohnny Bull who sat near
said it was a young Whale.
us said it was a young Whale.
Hurrah! He spouted away
throwing the spray 20 ft. high.
No sensation of sickness yet.
All is exhilerationexhilaration—watched the
Sun go down in splendor—
Joyed in the round sweep of
the horizon, & in the prospect
beyond.— Julia began to
grow a little uneasy. She
went to her birthberth & soon drop-
ped asleep. I watched the
process of setting sail, One
of the Officers put the
Sailors through in pretty
style. The breeze is slight &
not very favorable—

Sick to day, but able to be
about. Dont think this Kind
of sea sickness so bad. Philo
& Lucy are not affected at all
was about more or less all
day—went to bed early &
slept sound. Julia pretty
sick. I had to keep on deck to
day—or give in.

Lay wretchedly all morning
Saw them cast log. It is get-
ting colder. Awful sick all
the afternoon. Realized the horrors.
Oh! This rolling, straining, rolling
all day—all night, with the
rushing—rushing—of the waves.
the afternoon. Realized the
horrors. Oh! this rolling,
straining, rolling all day—
all night, with the rushing—

when will the end come?
Not for more than a week—
Poor Julia—have not seen

div.head:
Wrote the above Friday—
have not been able to do
anything except lay sick
since, up to this time—viz.
div.p:
It is a beautiful morning.
The sun shines through the cab-
in window down upon me
laying like a log in the
gentlemen's cabin. The voyage
is just getting "tolerable
& not to be endured".
is just getting "tolerable &
not to be endured".
In Much Ado About Nothing, Act 3, Scene 3, Dogberry says "for the watch to babble and to / talk is most tolerable and not to be endured." Julia
is yet in her birth berth—somewhat
better I believe. I have ac-
tually breakfasted on two
eggs,toast & tea. Here for
better I believe. I have actual-
ly breakfasted on two eggs,
toast and tea. Here for
days have I been sipping
beef tea—porridges—soups,
and such other watery and
wishy washy aliment, only
fit for the spectre of Melan-
choly, to wit, "a gibed Cat
in a garret." Possibly an allusion to Washington Irving's Tales of a Traveller. In "Buckthorne: or, The Young Man of Great Expectations," Irving writes, "whatever may be said of the gravity of a monkey, or the melancholy of a gibed cat, there is no more melancholy creature in existence than a mountebank off duty" (107). Had many
of these I loathed. "Have
anything to day"—says kind
John Miller, our serventservant—
John Miller, our serventservant:
"No!" is the sharp retort
of the sea sick soul. Is it
not horrible. It makes me
feel as if imprisonment for
ten days on bread & water with
whippings hourly would be
a delight. And then the idea
of coming back! I have been
thinking of that. Wonder if
there isn't some short cut
over Behrings straitBering Strait —No
matter for the bad roads
& cold weather — So its old
Mother Earth. But I trust
the BilousBilious is about exorcised,
& a better spirit of Health has
been elected President of my
temporal temple. That's a conso-
lation for the Reason, but it
don't dont
address itself to the
feelings. Wonder if a person
can feel religiously—or grand-
ly—or perceive the beautiful
under the full sway of sea
sickness My experience is
adverse to any other feeling
than Burkes sublimity of
Spenser's
cave of Error—"the
cave of Error—the
nauseate sublime"

On Sunday we passed
six
bona bonna
fide icebergs— Judging from the mileage recorded in its log, the RMS Asia probably encountered icebergs while running near the "Flemish Cap" of the Grand Banks off the Newfoundland coast. In The Physical Geography of the Sea (1855), M. F. Maury describes the contemporary understanding of the currents that carry icebergs to the coast of Newfoundland: "cold waters, as they come down from the Arctic Ocean through Davis's Straits, press upon the warm waters of the Gulf Stream, and curve their channel into a horse-shoe. . . . This 'bend' is the great receptacle of the icebergs which drift down from the north" (241–42).
Maury, Plate VI)
Map of the Gulf Stream in the North Atlantic.
Had each one been as golden
as oranges, as many hued as
Had each one been as gold-
en as oranges, as many hued as
the Trinity Church we saw in
Brooklyn, reduplicated in
Brooklyn reduplicated in
splendors and all gemmed
in glory, with a Polar bear
on each pinnacle of diamond.
I don't believe the scene could
have arroused my sense of
the Το Καλον. It was drow-
ned in the ocean of sea Sickness
fathomlessly—
the Το Καλον. It was drown-
ed in the ocean of sea-sick
ness fathomelessly.

We have had rough times
since Saturday—running over
the New foundland banks.
I had no idea we had to
run into these Hyperborean
regions. N. W. has been our
ruin. Pitch & strain
on— on
old Asia, you do up your
duty nobly. Up to
yesterday yestray
she is ahead of her
fastest time by seven
hours, and running at
the rate of 315 miles pr day.
We passed yesterday morn,
a schooner, which I did not
see. It danced from valley
to mountain—a thing of
wondrous vitality & beauty.
No sails on—going W.—What
a strange little wanderer—
1500 miles from either hemis-
phere, playing hide & go
1500 miles from either hemi-
sphere, playing hide & go
seek in the Northern billows.

We also hove in
sight of the N S Steamer
HumboltHumboldt—it is her first
tip in the ocean path! We
over came her by 5 o'clock
We also hove in sight
of the N Y Steamer HumboltHumboldt
It is her first in the
ocean path.
We over took her by 5 o'clock.
Our ladies didn't like the
idea of the British Steamer
beating her & it made me
feel a little sore to see
the stars & stripes left
behind. I actually with
feel a little sore to see the
stars & stripes left behind.
I actually with Philo's
Philo's aid, aid,
went up stairs
to see the race. We ran
along side for some miles,
only distant ½ mile. She
strained every nerve. We
saluted her with 4 guns.
Although not expecting
our courtesy she gave
us two booms. We had
ten pieces of canvass spread
to a fine W.west breeze. She
only had seven. How finely
she dashed the foam from
her black prow. what a
thing of throbbing life
& grandeur is a steam
ship! How magnificent
the race was! The boats
seemed to hold command
on the waters. So admira
bly is ours managed
that it seems a perfect
ark of safety. The Captain
& officers are of the R.N.Royal Navy, &
the men work so cheerily.
The harshness of subordina
tion is entirely lost in the
perfection of the system.
Not a throb of the engine
has been lost since we first
left the Pilot: If we get
to Liverpool by Saturday
at 12 M. it will be the
first & fastest trip on
record. 9 d. & 18 hours. The
Pacific made 9 d. & 20 hours. The Pacific belonged to the Collins Line, which competed for the Atlantic trade in the years following 1849. It and its sister ships, the Arctic, Baltic, and Atlantic, were somewhat larger than the Asia at 282 feet, with a gross tonnage of 2,800 and an indicated horse-power of 2,000. While the lines' competition extended to passenger accommodations and rates charged for freight, the speed of the Atlantic crossing especially caught the public's imagination (Babcock 92–95).

There is something after
all exciting & novel in
this sea sailing. The expanse
of water—the sailor's cry
the English modes—(&
they have been good)
the anticipation of being
in person upon the shores of
our progenitors—the land of
Shakespeare, Milton, Cromwell,
Pilgrims, Blackstone, Guy
Fawkes, Brougham, Walter
Scott, et cet—Is it not great?

If it were not for this Melan
choly sea sickness—
"all other griefs to this are Jolly
Naught so damned is Melancholy" See Burton, Anatomy of Melancholy (1660), "The Author's Abstract of Melancholy": "All my griefs to this are jolly, / Naught so damn'd as melancholy" (xiv).
of this nature!

The passengers are good, social
men—plenty of ladies & children
aboard. A good many clever
Scotchmen. How like Yankees
Scotch are!—

I wish Julia felt as well as I
this morngmorning. It is quite a relief
to be able thus to give vent
"No pent up Utica" Jonathan M. Sewall, Epilogue to Cato (1778). can contract
my powers" now,— for we
are aloof from all the res-
straintsrestraints of Earth—alone upon
a mobile element —not however
to drift—but to be ruled by the
consummate mastery of man
over the brute elements.

Was there ever such perfection
of enginery—so massive yet so
perfect; so powerful so fit—
Let the old Sea King Nep, try
his prettiest, as he has been, to
crack over his knee our joints
& sinews, cheerily sing the
Sailors and joyfully laugh
the children, who frisk about
the boat—!

As to my personnel—I am
a—Beauty! hirsute for a week—
pale & haggard; an exhalation
from "Death the Skeleton and
Time; the Shadow!".William Wordsworth, Yew Trees This is
pleasure travelling. The less
that is said about the better.

When I was first sea sick,
Philo asked me if I would take
a passage back in a fishing
smack from Newfoundland—
"Pshaw!" said I, indignantly
at the suggestion of want of
pluck; but—a sort of hanker-
ing after the steady hills of
Zanesville's vicinity floated, all
green & flowery, with visions
of carpettedcarpeted rooms, snug fires
and easy dressing gowns and
Aunt Ann's Kindness—through
my mind—. I would go it
over again rather be accounted
pluckless. Such is human
nature.—Columbus was
a hero! I have put him up
as the cap sheaf in my vol-
ume of hero worship—. Capt.
Cook was not, a small man
either.—

We passed last week some of
Mother Cary's chickens— Wilson's Storm Petrel (Oceanites oceanicus) (Turnbull; Patuxent Wildlife Research Center). I
saw too, a little tiny bird, "all
alone—all alone" Presumably an allusion to Coleridge's The Ancient Mariner: "Alone, alone, all alone; / Alone on a wide, wide sea" (pt. IV, st. 3). seemingly
exhausted; yet still flying
in its own element. What a
lesson does the aerial pilgrim
teach us. We who are continually
passing the limits of worldly
wisdom, and striving for the
unknown yet unapproachblyunapproachably
guarded mysteries of God and
the spirit world—does it not
teach us to be content in our
own sphere of Knowledge.
How beautiful would be the
song of that little chorister
upon a "bough swaying in
the breeze," in some sequestered
nook amid a leafy valley
surrounded with green prospects
& smiling cultivation. How like
a hymn to its Creator, would go
up its carol to the all Audient
Creator;—yet here it is, with fagged
wing & panting breast, contending
with harsh cold blasts, just able
to overtop the snow spray of the
mid Ocean,—deluded from its
home in the bosom of the wood by
the mysteries of the Unknown,
a thing of song in a sea
of Chaos—soon to be whelmed for-
ever! Is it not an epitome
of Man when he breaks the
golden chords of that harmony
which binds him to his
God!

Methinks ma petite oiseau
has been somewhat similarly
situated only with Hope's
untiring flutter to support
her sinking spirit!

A week afloat—To night at
10 o'clock I resume my journal.
The vessel rolls with diminished
Coal-ballast. The sailors sing
merrilly as they tug at the ropes.
Philo & Lucy are above. I
have just left Julia in her
birthberth, where we have had a
good conversional time. Lucy
has just joined her. Since Mon-
day have been pretty well over
the sea sickness; only so light-
headed that I couldn't sit
up. Was on deck yesterday
& today. Descried a solitary
vessel to the South. Have filled
or killed Time in reading Scott
novels—Black Dwarf and
old Mortality. Julia is
reading them after me—
I commence "The heart of
Mid Lothian" tomorrow—

Have just ordered a bottle
of hot water for Julia's feet.
These boats are cold—not
much danger from fire—
We shall soon be in Liver-
pool. How liquidly the
name will melt in the
mouth. This relief to the
Atlantic and ourselves
will be relieved. Philo
returns. It is time to
be abed. Won't be in
Liverpoool till 9 o'clock
Saturday, on account of
the tide—Wind's in our teeth.
Well, we hope for the best —

Had a good breakfast on boiled
eggs in the shell (a la mode Anglais)
& tea. It is my most refreshing meal
I tipped the End of my taste into Sir
W Scotts 'M Lothian'— & came on
deck where I found an air as mild
as that which Softly blows
O'er Ceylon's isle See the missionary hymn "From Greenland's Icy Mountains," by Bishop Reginal Heber: "What though the spicy breezes / Blow soft o'er Ceylon's isle" (Robinson 446).
I sit now on the steps of the upper
deck, the sailors are putting up
their ropes into snaky coils, the sound
of dishwashing romantically mingles
with the 'profound Eternal bass' See The Course of Time, by Robert Pollok (1798–1827): "Great Ocean! stongest of creation's sons, / Unconquerable, unreposed, untired, / that rolled the wild, profound, eternal bass, / In nature's anthem" (239). of
Ocean's roar. French fops and
English cockneys smoke cigars, whose
light vapor darts away to blend
with the blue that bends, like an
unbroken canopy, all around us!
What a circle, the horizon always
makes! I don't know whether it
pleases me most from its per-
fect geomotrygeometry or its vast extent.
The waverings of the water are
softened in the distance. It seems
as if God from the center of the
concave had by his Power carved
out a vast liquid gem, variant
with lights and shades, and fearful
as the jewels which shine upon
the Jewish Priest. See Exodus 28: 15-19.

Not a sail is set. The wind is
against us. "We scud under bare
poles on this raging canal."

Just passed me that English Cockney
whose ill mannered impertinence
we remarked at Brougham's during
Mary Taylor's performance of the
"Fille du Regiment."

Julia is better this morning. I
think she will be improved by the
Journey.

Capt.Captain of the deck is in a
stew. "Stir it! Men stir it out!
Men in the rigging want help.
Hammers—coal chisels & I can't
tell you what all—coming down
on us."—Whew!—They are taking
down the horizontal beam: If it
is not the boom—Je ne scaissçais quoi.

The water seems darker and
deeper. Would that I could
pierce its depths for a moment
as if it were the "sea of crystal,"
and see as it were preserved in
statu quo, the different objects of
the deep. Perhaps in the middle
depths where the hydraulic pressure
prevents further gravity, we would
see "whole navies" and argosies
rich with the spoils of Time—
floating or lying perdu.

The sea as you approach
the horizon's edge grows more
darkling, until upon its rim
where it clasps the sky, it is black.
Whether this is the result of the
contrast between the bright
heaven and the dark sea, or
whether it is the result of the
perspective I will not say. Of
both perhaps.

What an infinity of angles
the wind makes the sea na
make! Like the agitation of
one overmastering Thought
upon a world of Mind. Each
mental medium reflects it
similiarly yet with its marked
difference. One, like a Bacon
or Newton rises with it, to the
very dome of heaven, flashing
it white and beautiful in the
Day. Its very foam displaying
the strength of the wave! Anoth-
er receives the power, & with
the docility of a child, protends
its tiny drop—it may be but a
drop from the spray of a
greater billow! — Resistance,
like our gallant steamer, on-
ly serves to make the waves
rise higher, lashing into snow
wreaths the black mass, just
as suffering educe out of the
poetic soul those "lillies of
the Sea" which forever adorn
our world."—

Vulcan & Neptune both
own the Asia. You can see
them now both in the rigging.
One fixing the rigging with his
hammer, enveloped in the
smoke of the huge pipe; the
other attending the ropes—Wind
& Fire both harnessed in this
ocean race. Fire most potent
for he goes despite the Wind!

Not yet in sight of land, expecting
to see "Swate Ireland" to night,
before the Sun dips his murky
head in the western wave—

The passage is becoming more
tolerable.—Nothing like being used
to it, as the fellow said at the
whipping post.—We are getting
quite well. The prospect of
reaching Liverpool tomorrow
noon, noon
has evanished until to-
morrow night—

Have finished reading Scott's
Mid Lothian. the latter part
drags. The scenery about Edin-
burgh however is finely
painted, painted
and
Jeanie Deans Jeanie Deans
will long
be remembered, as one of the
bright acquaintances of this lu-
gubrious passage. Edith Bel-
lenden in Old Mortality, is
another illustration of the way
Scott can deliniate the female
character!

Was on deck to daytoday. As we
approach G.Great BritBritain, the Divinity
of Drizzle, which rules the Isle,
has begun to show her power.
Went to the bow, watched the white
foam boil under our velocity.
The Sailors were getting out
the anchor cables, with a jolly
song. We have come only about
3125 miles — the direct route is
about 3400 — We save the differ-
ence, altho' we make two sides
of the triangle—because, our
world is round.

The Officers are accustomed
every log to drop a bucket &
take the temperature of the
water. These reports are sent
perhaps to Greenwich; and there
are generalized into vital prin-
ciples of Navigation. So much
from a bucket of water and
Bacon's Induction!

All on the look out for land.
Man at the mast head &
Captain with a glass! Hurrah!
the home of our infranchise-
mentenfranchisement draweth nigh!

At about seven PM went on deck.
It was raining. I clambered up by
a tarred rope to look over, — when
horror of horrors! we were within
25 yards of a huge black rock —
rising out of the sea like the back
of Leviathan! I involuntarily drew
down. We were in sight of land.
The rock lies a few miles from
Cape Clear. The night was rainy—
The light houseslighthouses could however
be distinguished. We did not
retire till nearly 12. The only mis-
givings I have had since we
ventured on the sea, was upon
retiring; but Tired Nature soon
yielded, and I slept to awake
about 8 AM of

Land in sight. We are running
along the coast of Ireland, &
rapidly approaching Liverpool,
passed the Cork coast in the night.
The tide will be against us. At
this time we have passed Cansore
Point, Ireland; & are pushing up
the channel between Wales &
Ireland, not far from sight
of Braichen point; The Officer
by my side who is guiding our
noble ship, says that we are
moving in a direct line to
HolyhedHolyhead. So that we cannot
be out of sight of land at any time. The
land visible in Ireland, is not the
coast, but the mountains. "Heavy a
port" says the officer, & the deflection
Eastward continues.—

Since writing the above, we
have run into the Sight
of England. I observed an
oval line of fineness delicate
and fibre thin, to our right.
It grew into form, vast and
palpable, until Holyhead,
AngleseaAnglesey, burst on us. It looked
the rock bound coast, we read
of. The rocks are all fissured
and grey as geese with salt.
No footing for landing—

The rocks impress one strangely.
We saw a beautiful little
bridge (not the Menai)
The Menai Suspension Bridge, since 1826, has connected the Welsh island of Anglesey to the mainland of Wales. lead
up to one of the outer rocks
We saw the piles & place for
the new harbour at Holyhead
for the Cunard line. The tide
was strong against us; &
yet continues. We took a pilot
aboard, who gave us a news-
paper, which was devoured by
14 at once. We are now (10 PM)
under his convoy. The boat
reels from side to side. The
cries of "Starboard" & "steady" ring
from the prow to the tiller.
And this is England! Glorious
old England, with all her
reccollectionsrecollections so glorious.
I have written to Father &
Medary, This is probably a reference to Colonel Samuel Medary, then editor of the Ohio Statesman. Upon Cox's return to the United States, he purchased a half share of the Ohio Statesman. This transaction was made public through a letter signed by S. Medary that was published in the Ohio Statesman. The History of Knox County reveals that Samuel Medary was referred to as Colonel Samuel Medary. This article also states that Colonel Samuel Medary was granted the postmastership in Columbus, Ohio. Samuel Medary's obituary in Ohio History connects Medary's work as editor of the Ohio Statesman and postmaster in Columbus, Ohio. giving full acc'tsaccounts of
our trip.—Julia has been so
much better, having finished
her Journal & devoured whole
cargos of bread & butter!—

Here we are, so snugly esconcedensconsed at the
Waterloo House, having partaken of a
12 o'clock breakfast.

We reached Liverpool last night
about 11. How I can describe my
feelings at the grand illumination
which flanked us up the Mersey. I would
liked to have seen the green—bright green
of the banks with their white cottages &
elegant residences; but no! a richer
treat was afforded. The Mersey looks
to be a mile wide, & as we approached
Liverpool the gas lights played like fairies
about us. The huge docks of Birkenhead
looked dark and gloomy as we passed.
They allow no fire about them. Fires
are rare here. As we would come
in range of one of the fine streets of
Liverpool the lights would form
a regiment of fires, extending the
perspective so finely! The vessel could
not be docked. The tide running out
So we had to go off on a lighter or
young ferry. Such a time, in passing
valices, through the Custom House hands
Were in hopes to have got off trunks too,
but failed. Paid servants, bid Asia
good bye, and walked the plank
Made the acquaintance of Mr Wallen
of Florence, who will be useful. Our
passengers that are worth remembering
are Mr Kelley & some Phila.Philadelphia men,
a Tennessee man &c.

Next came the hurrah & exquisite
delight of landing. We touched the
dock: & I fairly capered. Philo
looked after Lucys trunk, I after
the ladies. We were first accosted by
the veritable O. Twist, who in his tatters
and with a bow & a touch of an apochry-
phalapocryphal cap, requested to carry the carpet
bag. After inquiring after Mr Twist,
a police man with a long hat & a
Nrnumber on his collar, touched Oliver, when he
mysteriously vamosedvamoosed. Next came was
a liar, s'dsaid, he was servant at Waterloo,
& as we preferred walking to the Hotel
he assumed the guide. Suspected he was
lying, and asked an officer, who s'dsaid
he was a servant. Soon came upon
another liar. "Waterloo Sir?:"— Sorry
it's full Sir, I am boots there" Sir,
Three ships just in. hrshours — Victoria
Hotel is near—great hotel &c..
Suspicious—moved on; the streets
looked so prim & neat. The houses
high & dark. St Saint Somebody's church
illumined showed & struck 2
in the morning. Cabs (one horse hasty
neat vehicles) rolled by over the
splendid paves. Policemen watched.
Our guide trotted along; girls in
a titter at the wild romance of
the nocturnal promenade.

Waterloo is reached. Ladies stood
ready to usher us in—took our names,
Julia ordered rooms, & soon we
were so cosily fixed.

All hands soon asleep. I
lay awake. The morn'gmorning was not
long in breaking. Slept till 11. It
was so nice to take coffee & tea
with muffins & chops, all four, Julia
presiding Tea Divinity, in our own
parlor. Didn't we Enjoy it?
Read London papers; & here, with
a good fire, a drizzly day & with
a room scented with flowers, of
which this petal Presumably, Cox refers to a sketch of a flower that he inserts at this point in the text:
Cox's sketch of a Johnny Jump-Up (Viola cornuta).
Cox's sketch of a Johnny Jump-Up (Viola cornuta)
is a
sample of a Johnny jump
up—all hands writing
for life,—do we begin
our Sunday afternoon.
We have had prayers, and feel so
happy & content. I like in such moods
to remember home. So here closes this
for letter writing—

After writing all day, at 1/2 5 P.M.
all sallied out to see this commercial
metropolis. We first were accosted by
two little vagrant girls or boys (could
not tell which,) they were dressed with
two rags a piece. One of them piloted
PPhilo. & LLucy. some squares, muttering like
a little gipsy, making a perfect
fretification come over us strange
people. Soon we got into the region
of splendid residences. The Corinthian
elegance of the architecture here &
the neatness & well pavedness of the
streets are prominent. The next thing is
the foliage. We went apast an enclo-
sure all leafy & laid out in walks—
a square, apparently public, but
with only a Summer house in it. A
full quoirquire of birds were sing a Sabbath
Anthem. Long iron bars were for fences.
We went west, apast such a bevy
of beautiful residences. Trees in front
& birds all about. Every house seemed
a Sister of the other. A beautiful Gothic
Chapel attracted our eye. The Bishop
of Chester was advertised to preach.
We went farther down apast what
seemed the RR.Railroad Depot & Exchange.
Both are magnificent pieces of archi-
tecture. The Corinthian is predomi-
nant. The capitals have so much
Elegant tracery. Passed a street
called "Roscoe," This street was named after William Roscoe (1783-1851), who was a Liverpool lawyer, historian, writer and philanthropist.
after the celebrated
Historian of the Medici. It recal-
led his name & Irving's Eloquent
tribute. See The Sketch Book of Geoffrey Crayon. Next came the Docks,
which we reached by passing thro'through
a grave yard, over grave stones,
which no one seems to mind here—
(horrible!) It was the grave
yard of a Solitary Chapel, upon
the side hill. Soon we saw the
shipping, with the "Washington,"
& GenGeneral Washingtons figure at the
head — Then following the rush
of people, saw the ferries leave for
the different points. Quite a
crowd were upon the quays. We
saw the docks. They were full of
water floating their masses of
timber & forests of masts, altho'although it
was low tide. It brings the ship-
ping away from the river, into
the city. The water was rushing
at a great rate into the Mersey
from them. Turning up we
pastpassed Maltese Sailors & all sorts
On our way up, we saw another
Church, with its grave stones all
bowed (as if ashamed) at the des-
ecration done to them by making
them a pavé. Returned to the
Waterloo, wearied; the ladies com-
plain of having been stared at
mildy— We saw the 'Adelphi'
It is an ex elegentelegant Hotel. But
I like ours.—

When does the day end here
It was light enough to write here
at 3 AM & now I am closing
this at 20m at 9.—

opener.dateline:
On the cars at Stafford, Monday
after 12:

div.p:
We are temporarily stopped.
Boys are crying the "Times,"—Mr Wallen
who is with us in the car, is reading from
the 'times'—The country which we have
passed through, has been one perfect
succession of rural beauties. After
leaving Liverpool, we walked around
to the rail way,— I got my life insured
for 3d.pence during our trip!

The tunnel out of Liverpool, is 1 1/4
mile, through the solid rock. We
moved over an inclined plane; by force
of a stationary engine. As soon as
we emerged, into the open air, every
eye opened at the perfect neatness
refreshing greenish green of the
nicely carpeted meadows.— We are
now moving away, still in sight of
a beautiful tower upon the hill at
our left. The peculiar chimneys &
the very red bricks of the houses, give
Stafford an air of rural comfort, only
equalled by every other part of this mag
nificent country. Nature seems as
if just washed in a shower, and so
bright, almost yellow in the green that
it pleases the eye strangely. The
churches, are mostly Gothic, and
peeping from amid the clump of
leafiness. I no longer wonder at the
love of rural life, the love of gardens
and meadows and walks & woods, &
parterres & terraces, so often the subject
of the English pastoral. The meads were
literally embroidered with butter cups, so
yellow, & daisies so white; while all along
our way we were lined with the hawthorn
hedges. Oh! those exquisite hedges, so
neat & trim, & green; parting neat fields
from their sister meads,—fields dotted with
the unwanted saffron furze, and silvered
along with little streams, to the very
edge of which the carpets of grass
extended. The hills were dotted all
over with the purest fleeces of
South downs; and the plains were
all spotted with the spotted Durham
cattle. Perfect pictures of pastoral
repose! Some of the fields were blue as
the sky with pansies. The cottages, how
many of them, were all ivied over, except
the high thatched roofs of slate or straw.
The land was of a reddish tinge, until
as we approached London,—near Layton,
a chalk formation appeared. Our agri-
culturist P. was perfectly struck
dumb at what Art had done for
Nature here so naturally sterile.
The common roads were all bound in with
with the green hedge & seemed as
smooth as winding garden paths. In-
deed the whole sweep of the country,
is one vast panorama of gardens.
The fields are deeply furrowed—those
for grain & with such exactitude as
give the appearance of taste and
heed to Every part! Nature seems
as if swept by the care of her child-
ren. Not a sign of poverty. The
manufacturing districts all seemed so
neat—Then long high chimney stacks
lifting themselves out of the level
land and at their top, tipped
with wavy streamers of smoke.
Yet even about the manufactories
is this same rural love. Each
railway station is a little Paradise
of Beauty. Grounds laid off so reg-
ularly. There does not seem to be a
sloven in all the land. Poverty as
I said, does not appear. Agriculture
is certainly not depressed here, for
every inch of land is taken. If 4
times as much is imported as
formerly & consumed, & they raise
more than they used to, has not
the Free Trade theory Done much!

The most noticeable object was
a fine Old Tower, upon a hill of
trees to the right. It commands
a prospect of the country, & has that
imposing air which an old castle
should have.

"Gentleman's' houses, are distinguish
ed from farmersfarmers', by the degree of
taste in the architecture. The science
of Agriculture seems advanced here
to its highest perfection!

Altogether we were gloriously ani-
mated, declaring that never thro'
our minds passed so many
examples of Beauty. It was like
a succession of landscapes in
a gallery, each "picked "
out for an example of the best."
Soon I descried the valley of the
"royal toward ThameThames"—its towers loom-
ing up and its splendid residences all
embowered as it were in a green setting
by a silver marge. Soon we came into
a Depot flanked on either side by splendid
residences & fine grassed plats. Singing
birds all around us. A cab soon
brought us wondering into famous
London town, where at Nonumber 13 Edw.Edward
Street Hampstead RhodesRoad, we slept,
until the

When we all started out for
the "Crystal palace."—
9 P.M. have returned, saw the immense
and glorious structure & what is more, its
multiform and splendid contents. Have
been on foot ever since we left, looking
only through a part of the palace—and such
an array of 'diamond & gold'—India's riches,
FrenichFrench elegance—German ingenuity, Italian
taste—American skill,—Turkish luxury
African oddity, & in fact, every imaginable
refinement—never was before put into
one place. It is the World's bizarrebazaar.
All of us were so agreeably disappointed.
The arrangement was only equalled by
the things arranged—Statuary, carpets,
bronze, fountains, trees, pagodas, Archi-
tecture—Indian rooms, Equestrian
statuary—all spread out into such
beauty. It was filled with the moving
mass.—Not disappointed in a thing!
the palace itself is a wonder; the
contents, more wonderful!

We got tired at 5 1/2—hired a cab,
came down apast Green Park; Saw
St James park in the distance,
the palace with the flag flying! As
we turned up out of Bond into Ox-
ford Street; Lo! a couple of outriders
dressed in red,—then a carriage
drawn by 6 horses with red riders;
then came two other riders with out livery;
then came two other red fellows with
canes, who looked so savage at a
hack driver, that didn't give way
immediately. Pretty soon, we saw
hats go off—Hurrah! it's the Queen!
I noticed her as they passed, but did
not observe anything ordinary—The
little boy was dressed nicely, with a
silver laced cap—A pretty little girl
sat with him in the front seat; &
a lady & somebody sat back. I asked
the driver if it was the Queen, he said
Yes—"Drive after them!" Away went
the sovereign of Gt B. Away after
went us Sovereigns in chase. The
outriders did not look savage at
us; & we got pretty close. Whereupon
to our open Eyes and outstretched
necks, the Queen herself
turned round & gave us a
good look & full view. We
had quite a good laugh at
our good fortune; came home full
of the Exhibition & of Royalty.

What an Eventful day! Never
before in my life has there been such
a day as this 21st April 1851; Cox erroneously writes "21st April" instead of "20th May."the
Crystal palace day—My brain is
almost dizzy with the splendors &
ingenuity of this Industrious World.
No wonder men labor, when such
may be produced, and such meed
of praise may follow.

To night for the opera & tomor-
row for Epsom.

Upon going up to day to the Exhibition
we passed the famous house of Duke
of Wellington, 'Apsley House'. I knew
it by the great bronze equestrian
statue of the Iron Duke. We also
saw on our return William Pitt, at
Hanover Sq. in full length with the
Scroll of Empire in his hand. What a
lofty bearing he had.

1/2 past 12. Have returned
from Princess' Theatre
The Princess Theatre was built just 10 years before Cox takes in the show (Lloyd). where we heard
Mr and Mrs Kean in 'Pauline'. Cox refers to Dion Boucicault's Pauline (1851).
They have
deteriorated—heard a piece called the
'Alhambra'.—a rich piece. Came home
tired. The London theatre does not exceed
those of N.Y.

div.p:
On the road to the great
Derby.—We started at 1/2 past 9.
Came down apast the statue of George
Canning, a splendid figure. Passed
Trafalgar Square, where we saw the
great Nelson monument, as well as the
monuments of GeoGeorge III &IV. The Nelson
monument has a very high shaft—

and a carving of the Battle of the Nile
upon the side next us. Soon we came
in sight of Old Westminster Abbey,
black & streaked, but full of interest
with its turrets, niches, tracery, towers,
"a wilderness of building."— Cox quotes William Wordsworth's "The Excursion." passed
over Vauxhall bridge, and were soon
in the pell mell, dashing hurrah
route to the Derby,—What a close
time we had. When 15 miles from
Epsom we were compelled to walk.
EvenAnd even stand still. Every kind
of vehicle from a dog cart to the
Prussian royal carriage, with cream
colored horses, was on the road.
Never had such a time. Lucy timid—
Julia sangfroid. Lord Strathmore
ran bump against us. At last
after passing through glorious roads
adorned with hedges, & beauteous
vistas, with a prospect from Epsom
downs over a vast range of varie-
gated yet beautiful country, we came
in sight of the stand. The downs
are covered with furze. With shouts
& laughter & hurrah! all hands dash
in on the turf. What a Scene! Who
can describe. A stake of $25,000,
is to be run for by 33 horses. At
least a half a million are on the
ground. The hack cleared, the cry is
they're off.—Away they dash!

Crowds, shouts, pigeons off. Such
a rush. Gipsies, circus, cries,
vendors—a regular tournament; a
fuss with a mean English puppy, who
insulted the ladies,—a drive thro'through
a beautiful country with it's vistas
of trees, ivies, and flowery carpettedcarpeted
meadows; and then through crowds
packed close over Westminster
home!—Tired enough I wrote to
Medary & father, then went to bed
at 1 PA.M.—

Philo & I took a cab, called
on Mr Laurence, the Minister, treated
us very kindly, gave us tickets,
went to the meeting of Americans
at Muraits. Then to Dr Malans,
who agreed to meet us at Greek
Slave The Greek Slave is a famous and controversial statue by American Neoclassical sculptor, Hiram Powers (1805-1873) (Crane 203). tomorrow 4 P.M; Thence
to Baring & Bros, Barings and Brothers was a London based merchant bank established in 1763 (Encyclopædia Britannica). through Picca-
dilly, Fleet, Threadneedle &
such familiar streets. Mr.
Sturges one of the firm very
kind. Left my stock business
with him. Also had our passports
visa'd to day. Got home by 5;
& wrote the rest of the day. The
ladies staid at home.

div.p:
Went to Exhibition, all through
the Nations, except Austria &
part of France. A perfect
day of confusion. Have made
a memo of what I have seen. It
is yet to be written out. The wonder
still grows on me. At 4 P.M. I
left the ladies in a cab to be
sent off home, when I struck for
Westminster and the House of Com-
mons, got in the Lord's lobby,
Was suprised at the Scene.
The hats of Members on—the
confusion. The following was
the debate The newspaper cutting that Cox pastes in his Journal is part of an editorial that appeared in the Times on Saturday, May 24, 1851 (5).
from the 'Times.'
div.quote:
The House of Commons having again resolved it-
self into a committee upon the Ecclesiastical Titles'
Assumption Bill,
Mr. T. Duncombe moved that the first clause be
postponed until the House was in possession of a
copy of the brief, rescript, or letters apostolical
upon which the enactment contained in that clause
was founded. It was not unreasonable, he thought,
that prior to ex-post facto legislation, inflicting pains
and penalties and annulling rights, this document
should be produced.
The Solicitor-General opposed the motion,
arguing that the legislation would be founded, not
upon the rescript, but upon the notorious fact de-
clared in the preamble, that divers of Her Ma-
jesty's Roman Catholic subjects had assumed certain
titles of pretended sees in the United Kingdom,
under colour of an alleged authority given to them
for that purpose by a certain brief, rescript, or let-
ters apostolical from the See of Rome.
The motion, which was supported by Mr. ROE-
BUCK, Mr. KEOGH, and Mr. REYNOLDS, and opposed
by the ATTORNEY-GENERAL and Mr. WALPOLE, was
negatived on a division by 221 against 49.
On the first clause,
Sir F.THESIGER moved, instead of the words
" the said brief, &c.," to insert the words "all such
briefs, &c.," intending to move corresponding
amendments in the preamble; his object being, he
said, to comprehend all similar rescripts which may
have been issued prior to the bill within the terms
of the declaratory enactment contained in this
clause.
The SOLICITOR-GENERAL thought Sir Frederick
had misconceived the scope and tendency of the
clause, which was not intended to revive the Statute
of Præmunire, which was unnecessary, but, in de-
ference to the opinion of Mr.Walpole, to make a
public and solemn declaration with reference to an
act of violence and aggression by a foreign poten-
tate, whereby certain subjects of the realm had
assumed certain titles and authority ; though he
(the SOLICITOR-GENERAL) thought the clause super-
fluous, in addition to the recital in the preamble,
the act being clearly illegal and void.
A long discussion ensued, in which the legal con-
struction and effects of the clause and the amend-
ment were very fully considered. At the suggestion of
Mr. Henley, Sir F. THESIGER consented to defer
the motion until the fate of an amendment in the
preamble announced by Mr. WALPOLE, which had a
concurrent object, was decided.
The Earl of ARUNDEL and SURREY then moved
another amendment of the first clause, by the inser-
tion of words expressly exempting from its operation
the use of such jurisdiction or title as shall be neces-
sary for the spiritual purposes, appealing to the avowal
of the Government that the bill was not intended
to interfere with spiritual functions.
The ATTORNEY-GENERAL objected to the amend-
ment, which would involve the inconguity of de-
claring the rescript, and all jurisdiction conferred
thereby, unlawful and void, and at the same time
recognizing its validity for certain purposes.
The amendment was supported by Mr. MOORE,
Mr. KEOGH, and Sir H. BARRON, and opposed by
LORD J. RUSSELL. On a division it was rejected by
316 against 61.
